'''Puppy Linux''' is a [[LiveCD]] [[Linux distribution]] that is very small and focuses on [[ease of use]]. The entire operating system and all the applications run from [[RAM]], allowing the boot medium to be removed after the [[operating system]] starts. Included are applications such as [[SeaMonkey]], [[AbiWord]], [[Sodipodi]], [[Gnumeric]], and Gxine/[[xine]]. The distribution was developed from scratch by Barry Kauler; it is not based on any other distribution.
+
'''Puppy Linux''' is a [[Live CD]] [[Linux distribution]] that is very small and focuses on [[ease of use]]. The entire operating system and all the applications run from [[RAM]], allowing the boot medium to be removed after the [[operating system]] starts. Included are applications such as [[SeaMonkey]], [[AbiWord]], [[Sodipodi]], [[Gnumeric]], and Gxine/[[xine]]. The distribution was developed from scratch by Barry Kauler; it is not based on any other distribution.
The latest release is 3.01, released on [[2007]]-[[10-15]].<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.puppylinux.com/news/ | title = Puppy version 3.01 released | first = Barry | last = Kauler }}</ref>
The latest release is 3.01, released on [[2007]]-[[10-15]].<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.puppylinux.com/news/ | title = Puppy version 3.01 released | first = Barry | last = Kauler }}</ref>
Line 60: Line 60:
*and an 83 MB "zdrv" standard edition, which contains more kernel drivers and firmware.
*and an 83 MB "zdrv" standard edition, which contains more kernel drivers and firmware.
â
Along with [[Morphix]], Puppy Linux is one of the few Linux LiveCD distributions able to save files to the LiveCD itself ([[multisession]]), allowing users to carry data, and more importantly, added programs and customized settings, along with them in the CD. Puppy-multisession is 55.7 MB.
+
Along with [[Morphix]], Puppy Linux is one of the few Linux Live CD distributions able to save files to the Live CD itself ([[multisession]]), allowing users to carry data, and more importantly, added programs and customized settings, along with them in the CD. Puppy-multisession is 55.7 MB.
Puppy 1 series will run comfortably on very dated hardware. For newer systems, the USB keydrive version might be better (although if USB device booting is not directly supported in the [[BIOS]], the Puppy floppy boot disk can be used to kick-start it). It is possible to [http://www.freeveda.org/linux/puppy/index.html run Puppy Linux with] [[Windows 9x]]/[[Windows Me]]. It is also possible, if the BIOS does not support booting from USB drive, to boot from the CD and keep user state on a USB keydrive; this will be saved on shutdown and read from the USB device on bootup.
Puppy 1 series will run comfortably on very dated hardware. For newer systems, the USB keydrive version might be better (although if USB device booting is not directly supported in the [[BIOS]], the Puppy floppy boot disk can be used to kick-start it). It is possible to [http://www.freeveda.org/linux/puppy/index.html run Puppy Linux with] [[Windows 9x]]/[[Windows Me]]. It is also possible, if the BIOS does not support booting from USB drive, to boot from the CD and keep user state on a USB keydrive; this will be saved on shutdown and read from the USB device on bootup.
